        187. 187
          Kopp, F.; Marahiel, M. A. Macrocyclization strategies in polyketide and nonribosomal peptide biosynthesis Nat. Prod. Rep. 2007, 24, 735â 749
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          187
          Macrocyclization strategies in polyketide and nonribosomal peptide biosynthesis
          Kopp, Florian; Marahiel, Mohamed A.
          Natural Product Reports (2007), 24 (4), 735-749CODEN: NPRRDF; ISSN:0265-0568. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          A review. Nonribosomal peptides and polyketides have attracted considerable attention in basic and applied research and have given rise to a multitude of therapeutic agents. The biol. activity of many of these complex natural products, including for example the peptide antibiotics daptomycin and bacitracin or the polyketide anticancer agents epothilone and geldanamycin, specifically relies on the macrocyclization of linear acyl chains that form the backbone of these highly valuable mols. The construction of the linear acyl precursors is accomplished by modular protein templates that follow comparable assembly line logic. As an enzymic key step, macrocyclization is introduced after the consecutive condensation of amino acid or acyl-CoA building blocks by dedicated catalysts, and the mature product is released from the biosynthetic machinery. The diverse chain termination strategies of nonribosomal peptide and polyketide assembly lines, the structures and mechanisms of the versatile macrocyclization catalysts, and chemoenzymic approaches for the development of new therapeutics are the focus of this review. Further, it is illustrated that macrocyclization is not restricted to secondary metabolites, but represents a commonly found structural motif of other biol. active proteins and peptides.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtVGrurjI&md5=fdebd4d7e79c975a6f829e22d6ff000c

          Developments in peptide and amide synthesis
          Albericio, Fernando
          Current Opinion in Chemical Biology (2004), 8 (3), 211-221CODEN: COCBF4; ISSN:1367-5931. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
          A review. The solid-phase methodol. is important for the effective synthesis of peptides, from a milligram scale for research to a multi-kilo scale for drug prodn. Indeed, small peptides contg. up to 20-30 amino acids are most readily synthesized by a solid-phase strategy. Larger peptides (up to 60 amino acids) should be synthesized by a convergent approach (i.e., synthesis of protected constituent peptides in solid-phase and combination of these units in soln.). Larger peptides and proteins are prepd. by chem. ligation, where unprotected segments have been prepd. in solid-phase.

          van Maarseveen, J. H. Solid phase synthesis of heterocycles by cyclization/cleavage methodologies Comb. Chem. High Throughput Screening 1998, 1, 185â 214
          [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          191
          Solid phase synthesis of heterocycles by cyclization/cleavage methodologies
          Van Maarseveen, Jan H.
          Combinatorial Chemistry and High Throughput Screening (1998), 1 (4), 185-214CODEN: CCHSFU; ISSN:1386-2073. (Bentham Science Publishers)
          Review with 67 refs. For the solid phase prepn. of various pharmacol. important heterocycles, cyclization/cleavage (CC) or cyclorelease strategies proved to be superior. CC approaches take utmost advantage of the benefits of solid phase synthesis. Besides the practical benefits of solid phase reactions, cyclizing release approaches are distinguished esp. because of the generally found high purity of the final detached products, since only the anticipated structures cleave off the resin. Also cyclization/cleavage strategies are traceless, as the obtained moiety after cyclization is part of the formed heterocycle. Over the last thirty years numerous approaches towards important heterocycle classes have been published. Among the successfully applied strategies are carbon-nitrogen (sulfur) bond, carbon-oxygen bond, sulfur-sulfur bond and carbon-carbon forming reactions in the final cyclorelease step.

          Holub, J. M.; Kirshenbaum, K. Tricks with clicks: modification of peptidomimetic oligomers via copper-catalyzed azide-alkyne [3 + 2] cycloaddition Chem. Soc. Rev. 2010, 39, 1325â 1337
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          200
          Tricks with clicks: modification of peptidomimetic oligomers via copper-catalyzed azide-alkyne [3 + 2] cycloaddition
          Holub, Justin M.; Kirshenbaum, Kent
          Chemical Society Reviews (2010), 39 (4), 1325-1337CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          A review. This tutorial review examines recent developments involving use of Copper-catalyzed Azide-Alkyne [3+2] Cycloaddn. (CuAAC) reactions in the synthesis, modification, and conformational control of peptidomimetic oligomers. CuAAC reactions have been used to address a variety of objectives including: (i) ligation of peptidomimetic oligomers; (ii) synthesis of ordered "foldamer" architectures; (iii) conjugation of ligands to peptidomimetic scaffolds; and (iv) macrocyclization of peptidomimetics using triazole linkages as conformational constraints. Variations in synthesis protocols, such as the use of different solvent systems, temps. and copper species are evaluated herein to present a range of variables for the optimization of CuAAC reactions. The overall objectives of these studies are assessed to highlight the widespread applications of the products, which range from bioactive ligands to new materials.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXjs1Ggurg%253D&md5=ce8d9896f87db72b3f1abea8730cfdf7

          Ring Closure to Î²-Turn Mimics via Copper-Catalyzed Azide/Alkyne Cycloadditions
          Angell, Yu; Burgess, Kevin
          Journal of Organic Chemistry (2005), 70 (23), 9595-9598CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
          Copper-catalyzed azide alkyne cycloaddns. of the linear substrates were used to form the macrocyclic derivs. For example, azido-alkyne peptide I was cyclized to form macrocycle II in 14% yield. Computational, NMR, and CD analyses of these compds. indicate that their most favorable conformational states include type I and type II Î²-turn conformations. Selectivity for the dimeric products in these cyclization reactions is discussed.

          Click chemistry reactions in medicinal chemistry: applications of the 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition between azides and alkynes
          Tron, Gian Cesare; Pirali, Tracey; Billington, Richard A.; Canonico, Pier Luigi; Sorba, Giovanni; Genazzani, Armando A.
          Medicinal Research Reviews (2008), 28 (2), 278-308CODEN: MRREDD; ISSN:0198-6325. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
          A review. In recent years, there has been an ever-increasing need for rapid reactions that meet the three main criteria of an ideal synthesis: efficiency, versatility, and selectivity. Such reactions would allow medicinal chem. to keep pace with the multitude of information derived from modern biol. screening techniques. The present review describes one of these reactions, the 1,3-dipolar cycloaddn. ("click-reaction") between azides and alkynes catalyzed by copper (I) salts. The simplicity of this reaction and the ease of purifn. of the resulting products have opened new opportunities in generating vast arrays of compds. with biol. potential. The present review will outline the accomplishments of this strategy achieved so far and outline some of medicinal chem. applications in which click-chem. might be relevant in the future.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXjsVerurg%253D&md5=ef565fc46c50047a6181e85711cb5c37

          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          204
          Click Chemistry as a Macrocyclization Tool in the Solid-Phase Synthesis of Small Cyclic Peptides
          Turner, Rushia A.; Oliver, Allen G.; Lokey, R. Scott
          Organic Letters (2007), 9 (24), 5011-5014CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7060. (American Chemical Society)
          1,2,3-Triazole-contg. macrocyclic peptides I {X = [(S)-COCH(CH2CHMe2)NH]n; n = 2-5} are prepd. chemoselectively by macrocyclization of resin-bound oligoleucine peptides attached to a resin via an L-propargylglycine ester and contg. N-terminal L-azidoleucine residues followed by cleavage from the resin. Macrocyclization reactions on resin using stoichiometric copper (I) bromide and L-ascorbic acid occur within 6 h at ambient temp., while the use of substoichiometric amts. of copper gives a mixt. of macrocycles and oligomers; mixts. of macrocyclic monomers contg. one triazole ring and macrocyclic dimers contg. two triazole rings are generated, in most cases favoring the monomeric macrocycles with chemoselectivities of >3:1. The structure of I (n = 3) is detd. by X-ray crystallog.; two crystallog. distinct mols. in the unit cell exist as type-I' and type-II' Î²-turn conformers, resp.

          205
          Thiol-click chemistry: a multifaceted toolbox for small molecule and polymer synthesis
          Hoyle, Charles E.; Lowe, Andrew B.; Bowman, Christopher N.
          Chemical Society Reviews (2010), 39 (4), 1355-1387CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          A review. The merits of thiol-click chem. and its potential for making new forays into chem. synthesis and materials applications are described. Since thiols react to high yields under benign conditions with a vast range of chem. species, their utility extends to a large no. of applications in the chem., biol., phys., materials and engineering fields. This crit. review provides insight into emerging venues for application as well as new mechanistic understanding of this exceptional chem. in its many forms (81 refs.).

          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          225
          Total Synthesis of Complestatin: Development of a Pd(0)-Mediated Indole Annulation for Macrocyclization
          Shimamura, Hiroyuki; Breazzano, Steven P.; Garfunkle, Joie; Kimball, F. Scott; Trzupek, John D.; Boger, Dale L.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (22), 7776-7783CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          Full details of the initial development and continued examn. of a powerful intramol. palladium(0)-mediated indole annulation for macrocyclization closure of the strained 16-membered biaryl ring system found in complestatin (1, chloropeptin II) and the definition of factors impacting its intrinsic atropodiastereoselectivity are described. Its examn. and use in an alternative, second-generation total synthesis of complestatin are detailed in which the order of the macrocyclization reactions was reversed from our first-generation total synthesis. In this approach and with the ABCD biaryl ether ring system in place, the key Larock cyclization was conducted with substrate 36 (contg. four phenols, five secondary amides, one carbamate, and four labile aryl chlorides) and provided the product 37 (56%) exclusively as a single atropisomer (>20:1, detection limits) possessing the natural (R)-configuration. In this instance, the complexity of the substrate and the reverse macrocyclization order did not diminish the atropodiastereoselectivity; rather, it provided an improvement over the 4:1 selectivity that was obsd. with the analogous substrate used to provide the isolated DEF ring system in our first-generation approach. Just as significant, the atroposelectivity represents a complete reversal of the diasteroselectivity obsd. with analogous macrocyclizations conducted using a Suzuki biaryl coupling.

          Denmark, S. E.; Muhuhi, J. M. Development of a general, sequential, ring-closing metathesis/intramolecular cross-coupling reaction for the synthesis of polyunsaturated macrolactones J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2010, 132, 11768â 11778
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          228
          Development of a General, Sequential, Ring-Closing Metathesis/Intramolecular Cross-Coupling Reaction for the Synthesis of Polyunsaturated Macrolactones
          Denmark, Scott E.; Muhuhi, Joseck M.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (33), 11768-11778CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          A general strategy for the construction of macrocyclic lactones contg. conjugated Z,Z-1,3-diene subunits is described. The centerpiece of the strategy is a sequential ring-closing metathesis (RCM) that forms an unsatd. siloxane ring, followed by an intramol. cross-coupling reaction with a pendant alkenyl iodide. A highly modular assembly of the various precursors allowed the prepn. of unsatd. macrolactones contg. 11-, 12-, 13-, and 14-membered rings. Although the RCM process proceeded uneventfully, the intramol. cross-coupling required extensive optimization of palladium source, solvent, fluoride source, and particularly fluoride hydration level. Under the optimal conditions (including syringe pump high diln.), the macrolactones were produced in 53-78% yield as single stereoisomers. A benzo-fused 12-membered-ring macrolactone contg. an E,Z-1,3-diene unit was also prepd. by the same general strategy. The E-2-styryl iodide was prepd. by a novel Heck reaction of an aryl nonaflate with vinyltrimethylsilane followed by iododesilylation
          >> More from SciFinder Â®

          Methods to initiate synthetic re-structuring of peptides
          Wei, Qi; Harran, Susan; Harran, Patrick G.
          Tetrahedron (2003), 59 (45), 8947-8954CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
          The authors present a protocol for the synthesis of macrocyclic peptide ethers via a multi-component condensation reaction followed by metal-catalyzed cycloetherification. For example, macrocycle I was obtained in two steps from the three-component condensation of reactants H-Gly-Tyr-NHBu, allyl carbonate II and isonitrile 4-FC6H4CH(Nâ¡C)SO2C6H4Me-4, followed by cyclization of the adduct in presence of catalysts [(Î·3-ally)PdCl]2 and van Leeuwen's Xantphos. The authors are currently studying the application of the above protocol to solid-phase synthesis.

          Zhao, H.; Negash, L.; Wei, Q.; LaCour, T. G.; Estill, S. J.; Capota, E.; Pieper, A. A.; Harran, P. G. Acid promoted cinnamyl ion mobility within peptide derived macrocycles J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2008, 130, 13864â 13866
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          230
          Acid Promoted Cinnamyl Ion Mobility within Peptide Derived Macrocycles
          Zhao, Hongda; Negash, Lidet; Wei, Qi; LaCour, Thomas G.; Estill, Sandi Jo; Capota, Emanuela; Pieper, Andrew A.; Harran, Patrick G.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (42), 13864-13866CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          We are developing methods that restrict the conformational mobility of peptides and related heteropolymers while simultaneously altering their properties. Our expts. occur as processes wherein a conserved, lipophilic reagent is activated in stages to form composite products with unprotected polyamides in parallel. For each starting oligomer, the goal is to create not one, but rather a collection of products. The intent is for those materials to retain mol. recognition elements of the biopolymer, yet display that functionality as part of stable, cyclic structures having defined shapes and enhanced membrane soly./permeability. Here, we describe reagent I and its two-step integration into peptides to afford macrocyclic ethers (e.g., II when starting with H-Gly-Trp-Tyr-NHBu). When those materials are treated with protic acid in anhyd. solvent, the cinnamyl unit migrates from the oxygen of tyrosine to distribute throughout the structure, forming new products via carbon/carbon bonding. These changes occur concomitantly with acid-promoted rearrangements/cyclizations of the dienyne appendage to generate mixts. contg. unique macrocycles. From a library of screening fractions generated in this way, we have identified a small mol. that selectively promotes hippocampal neurogenesis in the adult mouse brain.

          Dufour, J. N., L.; Zhu, J. Intramolecular SuzukiâMiyaura reactions for the total synthesis of signal peptidase inhibitors, arylomycins A2 and B2 Chem.âEur. J. 2010, 16, 10523â 10534
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          233
          Intramolecular Suzuki-Miyaura reaction for the total synthesis of signal peptidase inhibitors, arylomycins A2 and B2
          Dufour, Jeremy; Neuville, Luc; Zhu, Jieping
          Chemistry - A European Journal (2010), 16 (34), 10523-10534, S10523/1-S10523/76CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          Development of the total syntheses of arylomycins A1 and B2 is detailed. Key features of our approach include (1) formation of 14-membered meta,meta-cyclophane by an intramol. Suzuki-Miyaura reaction; (2) incorporation of N-Me-4-hydroxyphenylglycine into the cyclization precursor, which avoids the late-stage low-yielding N-methylation step; (3) segment coupling of a fully elaborated peptide side chain to the macrocycle, which makes the synthesis highly convergent. Overall, arylomycin A2 was obtained in 13 steps from L-Tyr for the longest linear sequence, in 13 % overall yield. Arylomycin B2 was synthesized in 10 steps from L-3-nitro-Tyr, in 10 % overall yield.

          Synthesis of Macrocyclic Peptide Analogues of Proteasome Inhibitor TMC-95A
          Berthelot, Alexandra; Piguel, Sandrine; Le Dour, Gwennaeel; Vidal, Joeelle
          Journal of Organic Chemistry (2003), 68 (25), 9835-9838CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)

          Akritopoulou-Zanze, I. Isocyanide-based multicomponent reactions in drug discovery Curr. Opin. Chem. Biol. 2008, 12, 324â 331
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          238
          Isocyanide-based multicomponent reactions in drug discovery
          Akritopoulou-Zanze, Irini
          Current Opinion in Chemical Biology (2008), 12 (3), 324-331CODEN: COCBF4; ISSN:1367-5931. (Elsevier B.V.)
          A review. This review describes recent advances in the application of isocyanide-based multicomponent reactions (IMCRs) in drug discovery and summarizes the various chemotypes used to probe biol. targets. In the past couple of years, IMCR-derived ligands have been used to develop agents against infectious diseases and to interfere with protein-protein interactions. Addnl., they were active against a variety of targets such as enzymes, GPCRs and ion channels. The rational for the chem. biologist to apply such diversity generating chemistries is also discussed.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXnt1ers78%253D&md5=9038f42a54ecb3f20232b1568818d6dd
        239. 239
          Hulme, C.; Gore, V. âMulti-component reactions: emerging chemistry in drug discoveryâ 'from xylocain to crixivan' Curr Med Chem 2003, 10, 51â 80
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          239
          Multi-component reactions: emerging chemistry in drug discovery from xylocain to crixivan
          Hulme, Christopher; Gore, Vijay
          Current Medicinal Chemistry (2003), 10 (1), 51-80CODEN: CMCHE7; ISSN:0929-8673. (Bentham Science Publishers)
          A review. With the recent emergence of combinatorial chem. and high-speed parallel synthesis for drug discovery applications, the multi-component reaction (MCR) has seen a resurgence of interest. Easily automated one-pot reactions, such as the Ugi and Passerini reactions, are powerful tools for producing diverse arrays of compds., often in one step and high yield. Despite this synthetic potential, the Ugi reaction is limited by producing products that are flexible and peptide-like, often being classified as "non drug-like". This review details developments of new, highly atom-economic MCR derived chem. methods, which enable the fast and efficient prodn. of chem. libraries comprised of a variety of biol. relevant templates. Representative examples will also be given demonstrating the successful impact of MCR combinatorial methods at different stages of the lead discovery, lead optimization and pre-clin. process development arenas. This will include applications spanning biol. tools, natural products and natural product-like diversity, traditional small mol. and "biotech" therapeutics resp. In particular, this review will focus on applications of isocyanide based MCR (IMCR) reactions. A review.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXisVSrtA%253D%253D&md5=4a38e495aa941010cd026d2ace1004d5
        240. 240
          Beck, B.; Larbig, G.; Mejat, B.; Magnin-Lachaux, M.; Picard, A.; Herdtweck, E.; Domling, A. Short and diverse route toward complex natural product-like macrocycles Org. Lett. 2003, 5, 1047â 1050
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          240
          Short and Diverse Route Toward Complex Natural Product-Like Macrocycles
          Beck, Barbara; Larbig, Gregor; Mejat, Beatrice; Magnin-Lachaux, Marina; Picard, Anne; Herdtweck, Eberhardt; Doemling, Alexander
          Organic Letters (2003), 5 (7), 1047-1050CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7060. (American Chemical Society)
          A general strategy toward macrocyclic compds. using multicomponent reaction (MCR) chem., e.g., Passerini and Ugi variants, and ring-closing metathesis (RCM) is introduced. The corresponding bifunctional isocyanides carboxylic acids bearing a terminal olefin are easy to prep. from the corresponding com. available starting materials. Advantageously, this strategy allows fast access to a diverse conformational space of natural product-like macrocycles I and II and could thus be of interest in the discovery of novel bioactive agents.

        242. 242
          Yudin, A. K.; Hili, R. Overcoming the demons of protecting groups with amphoteric molecules Chemistry 2007, 13, 6538â 6542
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          242
          Overcoming the demons of protecting groups with amphoteric molecules
          Yudin, Andrei K.; Hili, Ryan
          Chemistry - A European Journal (2007), 13 (23), 6538-6542CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          A review. Synthetic org. chemists have long depended on protecting group manipulations when faced with the challenges of chemoselectivity and functional group incompatibility. Overcoming this dependence will improve the overall efficiency of chem. synthesis. By taking advantage of orthogonally reactive functional groups, amphoteric mols. can afford access not only to more efficient and strategic syntheses but also to the development of novel chem. transformations.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®

        249. 249
          Swamy, K. C.; Kumar, N. N.; Balaraman, E.; Kumar, K. V. Mitsunobu and related reactions: advances and applications Chem. Rev. 2009, 109, 2551â 2651
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          249
          Mitsunobu and Related Reactions: Advances and Applications
          Swamy, K. C. Kumara; Kumar, N. N. Bhuvan; Balaraman, E.; Kumar, K. V. P. Pavan
          Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2009), 109 (6), 2551-2651CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
          In this review is an attempt to detail the Mitsunobu reaction, along with its modifications, which has been versatile and applicable for a variety of org. transformations. The ease with which stereochem. at the chiral secondary alc. can be reversed is a valuable asset. The large no. of publications, particularly in the area of nucleobase alkylation, reflects its popularity, mainly as a result of the mild conditions employed during the reaction. It is expected that this aspect is going to be much sought after, particularly by the pharmaceutical industry. Synthetic chemists tend to rely on its various facets, be it natural product synthesis or nucleobase alkylation or etherification. As far as the future of this reaction is concerned, an efficient and inexpensive way to recycle the reagents or to make the reaction fully catalytic is desirable. Another aspect worth looking into would be to synthesize a water sol. but degradable phosphine/phosphite of low toxicity, to simplify the purifn. process. The aforesaid points become important if we desire to employ the Mitsunobu route for large scale synthesis. Recoverable polymer bound phosphonium salts of type 565 that avoid the wastage of phosphine as well as azodicarboxylate, and hence make the system more atom economical and greener, also need to be considered in the future. Finally, although a major part of the mechanistic pathways is fairly well understood, the complexity of the initial steps when different P precursors are used is intriguing. This could also be a fruitful area for a phys. org. chemist to probe in detail.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXkvVagt78%253D&md5=f7da5265d707fafe71cb40dea76dc1e9

          258
          Efficient Large-Scale Synthesis of BILN 2061, a Potent HCV Protease Inhibitor, by a Convergent Approach Based on Ring-Closing Metathesis
          Yee, Nathan K.; Farina, Vittorio; Houpis, Ioannis N.; Haddad, Nizar; Frutos, Rogelio P.; Gallou, Fabrice; Wang, Xiao-Jun; Wei, Xudong; Simpson, Robert D.; Feng, Xuwu; Fuchs, Victor; Xu, Yibo; Tan, Jonathan; Zhang, Li; Xu, Jinghua; Smith-Keenan, Lana L.; Vitous, Jana; Ridges, Michael D.; Spinelli, Earl M.; Johnson, Michael; Donsbach, Kai; Nicola, Thomas; Brenner, Michael; Winter, Eric; Kreye, Paul; Samstag, Wendelin
          Journal of Organic Chemistry (2006), 71 (19), 7133-7145CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
          A multistep scalable synthesis of the clin. important hepatitis C virus (HCV) protease inhibitor BILN 2061 (1) is described. The synthesis is highly convergent and consists of two amide bond formations, one etherification, and one ring-closing metathesis (RCM) step, using readily available building blocks 2-5. The optimization of each step is described at length. The main focus of the paper is the study of the RCM step and the description of the main problems faced when scaling up to pilot scale this highly powerful but very challenging synthetic operation. Eventually, the RCM reaction was smoothly scaled up to produce >400 kg of cyclized product.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xot1KgsL4%253D&md5=c624c44d7818034d362fc8798cb83d09
        259. 259
          Shu, C.; Zeng, X.; Hao, M. H.; Wei, X.; Yee, N. K.; Busacca, C. A.; Han, Z.; Farina, V.; Senanayake, C. H. RCM macrocyclization made practical: an efficient synthesis of HCV protease inhibitor BILN 2061 Org. Lett. 2008, 10, 1303â 1306
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          259
          RCM macrocyclization made practical: An efficient synthesis of HCV protease inhibitor BILN 2061
          Shu, Chutian; Zeng, Xingzhong; Hao, Ming-Hong; Wei, Xudong; Yee, Nathan K.; Busacca, Carl A.; Han, Zhengxu; Farina, Vittorio; Senanayake, Chris H.
          Organic Letters (2008), 10 (6), 1303-1306CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7060. (American Chemical Society)
          We report here that dramatic improvement of the key RCM reaction in the synthesis of HCV protease inhibitor BILN2061 can be achieved by N-substitution of the diene substrate with an electron-withdrawing group. Mechanistic studies using 1H NMR spectroscopy showed an unprecedented switch of the initiation sites and the correlation between such switch and the results of RCM, from the unmodified to the modified substrates. We also provided theor. evidence that such modification may also increase the thermodn. preference of the macrocyclic product over the diene substrate.

          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          267
          DNA-Templated Organic Synthesis and Selection of a Library of Macrocycles
          Gartner, Zev J.; Tse, Brian N.; Grubina, Rozalina; Doyon, Jeffrey B.; Snyder, Thomas M.; Liu, David R.
          Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2004), 305 (5690), 1601-1605CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
          The translation of nucleic acid libraries into corresponding synthetic compds. would enable selection and amplification principles to be applied to synthetic mols. We used multistep DNA-templated org. synthesis to translate libraries of DNA sequences, each contg. three "codons," into libraries of sequence-programmed synthetic small-mol. macrocycles. The resulting DNA-macrocycle conjugates were subjected to in vitro selections for protein affinity. The identity of a single macrocycle possessing known target protein affinity was inferred through the sequence of the amplified DNA template surviving the selection. This work represents the translation, selection, and amplification of libraries of nucleic acids encoding synthetic small mols. rather than biol. macromols.

          A Strategy for Macrocyclic Ring Closure and Functionalization Aimed toward Split-Pool Syntheses
          Lee, Daesung; Sello, Jason K.; Schreiber, Stuart L.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (1999), 121 (45), 10648-10649CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)

I [R1 = Ph, R2 = CH2OMe, R3-R5 = H] was also prepd. on a solid support, demonstrating that the method is useful for combinatorial synthesis.

          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXmvFCkurs%253D&md5=498ae58180a26442b207fba0369e7bca
        276. 276
          Kim, Y. K.; Arai, M. A.; Arai, T.; Lamenzo, J. O.; Dean, E. F., 3rd; Patterson, N.; Clemons, P. A.; Schreiber, S. L. Relationship of stereochemical and skeletal diversity of small molecules to cellular measurement space J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2004, 126, 14740â 14745
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          276
          Relationship of Stereochemical and Skeletal Diversity of Small Molecules to Cellular Measurement Space
          Kim, Young-kwon; Arai, Midori A.; Arai, Takayoshi; Lamenzo, Julia O.; Dean, Elton F., III; Patterson, Nick; Clemons, Paul A.; Schreiber, Stuart L.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (45), 14740-14745CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          Systematic and quant. measurements of the roles of stereochem. and skeleton-dependent conformational restriction were made using multidimensional screening. We first used diversity-oriented synthesis to synthesize the same no. (122) of [10.4.0] bicyclic products (B) and their corresponding monocyclic precursors (M). We measured the ability of these compds. to modulate a broad swath of biol. using 40 parallel cell-based assays. We analyzed the results using statistical methods that revealed illuminating relationships between stereochem., ring no., and assay outcomes. Conformational restriction by ring-closing metathesis increased the specificity of responses among active compds. and was the dominant factor in global activity patterns. Hierarchical clustering also revealed that stereochem. was a second dominant factor; whereas the stereochem. of macrocyclic appendages was a determinant for bicyclic compds., the stereochem. of the carbohydrates was a determinant for the monocyclic compds. of global activity patterns. These studies illustrate a quant. method for measuring stereochem. and skeletal diversity of small mols. and their cellular consequences.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXos1Kmsb0%253D&md5=d336b452424e1b3a7e23e487268fc95a
        277. 277
          Schmidt, D. R.; Kwon, O.; Schreiber, S. L. Macrolactones in diversity-oriented synthesis: preparation of a pilot library and exploration of factors controlling macrocyclization J. Comb. Chem. 2004, 6, 286â 292
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          277
          Macrolactones in Diversity-Oriented Synthesis: Preparation of a Pilot Library and Exploration of Factors Controlling Macrocyclization
          Schmidt, Darby R.; Kwon, Ohyun; Schreiber, Stuart L.
          Journal of Combinatorial Chemistry (2004), 6 (2), 286-292CODEN: JCCHFF; ISSN:1520-4766. (American Chemical Society)
          A linker-and-bead combination was used to prep. macrolactones. Protected hydroxy acids were prepd. and used to load the resin. A second hydroxy acid was then coupled to the one on the resin. E.g., alc. I was prepd. and loaded onto the resin. Deesterification of I and addn. of alc. II in soln. was followed by macrocyclization to give III. Synthesis of the monomers involved Sharpless asym. dihydroxylation and use of allyl esters and 4-methoxybenzyl ethers as protected intermediates. A library of macrolactones was prepd. from a variety of starting materials.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXmtV2nsQ%253D%253D&md5=cf34c0ee908ccb33d0e2e575c05ee552
        278. 278
          Peng, L. F.; Stanton, B. Z.; Maloof, N.; Wang, X.; Schreiber, S. L. Syntheses of aminoalcohol-derived macrocycles leading to a small-molecule binder to and inhibitor of Sonic Hedgehog Bioorg. Med. Chem. Lett. 2009, 19, 6319â 6325
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          278
          Syntheses of aminoalcohol-derived macrocycles leading to a small-molecule binder to and inhibitor of Sonic Hedgehog
          Peng, Lee F.; Stanton, Benjamin Z.; Maloof, Nicole; Wang, Xiang; Schreiber, Stuart L.
          Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2009), 19 (22), 6319-6325CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier B.V.)
          The synthesis and biol. activity of a library of aminoalc.-derived macrocycles I [X = (CH2)n; n = 1 - 3; R = H, Ph] from which robotnikinin (2R,6S)-I (X = CH2, R = Ph), a binder to and inhibitor of Sonic Hedgehog, was derived. An asym. alkylation reaction and a ring-closing metathesis reaction were used to set a key stereocenter and to close the macrocycle, resp. High-throughput screening via small-mol. microarray technol. led to the discovery of a compd. capable of binding ShhN. Follow-up chem. led to a library of macrocycles with enhanced biol. activity relative to the original hit compds. Differences in ring size and stereochem., leading to alterations in the mode of binding, may account for differences in the degree of biol. activity. These compds. are the first ones reported that inhibit Shh signaling at the ShhN level.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtlWlsrfO&md5=457e4ccb6fce4512fe5e3430dfa1d87e
        279. 279
          Morton, D.; Leach, S.; Cordier, C.; Warriner, S.; Nelson, A. Synthesis of natural-product-like molecules with over eighty distinct scaffolds Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2009, 48, 104â 109
          [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          279
          Synthesis of natural-product-like molecules with over eighty distinct scaffolds
          Morton, Daniel; Leach, Stuart; Cordier, Christopher; Warriner, Stuart; Nelson, Adam
          Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2009), 48 (1), 104-109CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          A synthetic approach for the combinatorial variation of the scaffolds of small mols. is described. Using just six basic reaction types, compds. with 84 distinct scaffolds were prepd. The compds. had many natural-product-like structural features including rich stereochem., heterocyclic and unsatd. ring systems, and dense functionalization.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXosFGmsQ%253D%253D&md5=a50405150961afb4a8067bf8610b6a1e
        280. 280
          Dai, C. F.; Cheng, F.; Xu, H. C.; Ruan, Y. P.; Huang, P. Q. Diversity-oriented asymmetric synthesis of hapalosin: construction of three small C9/C4/C3-modified hapalosin analogue libraries J. Comb. Chem. 2007, 9, 386â 394
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          280
          Diversity-Oriented Asymmetric Synthesis of Hapalosin: Construction of Three Small C9/C4/C3-Modified Hapalosin Analogue Libraries
          Dai, Chao-Feng; Cheng, Fang; Xu, Hai-Chao; Ruan, Yuan-Ping; Huang, Pei-Qiang
          Journal of Combinatorial Chemistry (2007), 9 (3), 386-394CODEN: JCCHFF; ISSN:1520-4766. (American Chemical Society)
          A flexible approach to the Î²-hydroxy Î³-amino acid residue (fragment C) of hapalosin has been developed on the basis of the the regio- and diastereoselective Grignard reaction. The method allows the introduction of different side chains at the C9 of hapalosin. Asym. syntheses of hapalosin, 9-homohapalosin, 9-iso-butylhapalosin, 8-epi-hapalosin, and three small libraries diversified at C9 (3-member, 1L3), C9/ C4 (9-member, 1L9), or C9/C4/C3 (27-member, 1L27) have been produced using this method.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXislKktb8%253D&md5=4530415b340f549e30746a754f30d3e2
        281. 281
          Beeler, A. B.; Acquilano, D. E.; Su, Q.; Yan, F.; Roth, B. L.; Panek, J. S.; Porco, J. A., Jr. Synthesis of a library of complex macrodiolides employing cyclodimerization of hydroxy esters J. Comb. Chem. 2005, 7, 673â 681
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          281
          Synthesis of a Library of Complex Macrodiolides Employing Cyclodimerization of Hydroxy Esters
          Beeler, Aaron B.; Acquilano, Dayle E.; Su, Qibin; Yan, Feng; Roth, Bryan L.; Panek, James S.; Porco, John A., Jr.
          Journal of Combinatorial Chemistry (2005), 7 (5), 673-681CODEN: JCCHFF; ISSN:1520-4766. (American Chemical Society)
          The synthesis of complex macrodiolides involving microwave-accelerated transesterification of chiral, nonracemic, hydroxy esters is described. Thus, reacting hydroxy esters I and II using [[F3C(CF2)5CH2CH2]2SnO]n as catalyst gave macrodiolide III in 99% yield. Methodol. development studies indicate that both microwave power and reaction temp. play an important role in the efficiency of cyclodimerizations. Hydroxy ester monomer pairs were evaluated using an anal. rehearsal leading to the prepn. of a 127-member library of highly diverse and stereochem. well-defined macrodiolides. Preliminary assays identified a novel macrodiolide antagonist, IV (Ts = SO2C6H4Me-4), of the Îº opioid receptor.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXmtVChtbY%253D&md5=42c552bdccdd3d4c43ca9dbb92c9ed57

          285
          Combinatorial Synthesis of RGD Model Cyclic Peptides Utilizing a Palladium-Catalyzed Carbonylative Macrolactamization on a Polymer Support
          Kamioka, Seiji; Shimazu, Sayaka; Doi, Takayuki; Takahashi, Takashi
          Journal of Combinatorial Chemistry (2008), 10 (5), 681-690CODEN: JCCHFF; ISSN:1520-4766. (American Chemical Society)
          A combinatorial synthesis of 24-member RGD models was accomplished on polymer-support. Ortho-, meta-, and para-iodobenzylamines loaded on an aldehyde linker by reductive amination were coupled with RGD sequences and various Ï-amino acids by a split-and-pool method. Palladium-catalyzed carbonylative macrolactamization of the polymer-supported cyclization precursors, followed by acid cleavage, provided conformationally restricted RGD model cyclic peptides.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXps1alsLw%253D&md5=dc66d16dbbc22467c313dcda073dd17f
        286. 286
          Biggs-Houck, J. E.; Younai, A.; Shaw, J. T. Recent advances in multicomponent reactions for diversity-oriented synthesis Curr. Opin. Chem. Biol. 2010, 14, 371â 382
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          286
          Recent advances in multicomponent reactions for diversity-oriented synthesis
          Biggs-Houck, James E.; Younai, Ashkaan; Shaw, Jared T.
          Current Opinion in Chemical Biology (2010), 14 (3), 371-382CODEN: COCBF4; ISSN:1367-5931. (Elsevier B.V.)
          A review is given on recent developments in multicomponent reactions (MCRs) as a rich source of mol. diversity. Interest in MCRs has surged during the past 2 decades as interest in the efficient synthesis of small mol. libraries has gained prominence. MCRs fill an important niche in library synthesis by providing direct access to library compds. and by serving as starting points for diversity-oriented synthesis (DOS). Recent advances in the area of MCR chem. have included the discovery of new reactions, development of asym. catalysts, and the application of MCRs to natural products and other targets of biol. interest.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXmvVWqsLk%253D&md5=cfab92a087ddab978df937ab9ebf4878

          Wessjohann, L. A.; Rivera, D. G.; Vercillo, O. E. Multiple multicomponent macrocyclizations (MiBs): a strategic development toward macrocycle diversity Chem. Rev. 2009, 109, 796â 814
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          287
          Multiple Multicomponent Macrocyclizations (MiBs): A Strategic Development Toward Macrocycle Diversity
          Wessjohann, Ludger A.; Rivera, Daniel G.; Vercillo, Otilie E.
          Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2009), 109 (2), 796-814CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
          This review presents basic principles of multiple multi-component macrocyclization methods. The approach is expected to develop to a valuable strategy for the synthesis of peptide-like or artificial macrocycles.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtVChtb0%253D&md5=d32b92ff49300a68adc2fa152e4cd8d0
        288. 288
          Rivera, D. G.; Vercillo, O. E.; Wessjohann, L. A. Rapid generation of macrocycles with natural-product-like side chains by multiple multicomponent macrocyclizations (MiBs) Org. Biomol. Chem. 2008, 6, 1787â 1795
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          288
          Rapid generation of macrocycles with natural-product-like side chains by multiple multicomponent macrocyclizations (MiBs)
          Rivera, Daniel G.; Vercillo, Otilie E.; Wessjohann, Ludger A.
          Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2008), 6 (10), 1787-1795CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          A small parallel library of peptoid macrocycles with natural-product-derived side chains of biol. importance was produced by Ugi-type multiple multicomponent macrocyclizations including bifunctional building blocks (Ugi-MiBs). Diverse exocyclic elements of high relevance in natural recognition processes, i.e., all functional amino acid residues (e.g., Cys, Arg, His, Trp) and even sugar moieties, can be introduced in a one-pot process into different types of peptoid-contg. macrocyclic skeletons. This is exemplified by the use of a diamine/diisocyanide combination of Ugi-MiBs and N-protected Î±-amino acids or carboxy-functionalized carbohydrates as source for the natural-product-like exocyclic elements. Employed as the acid components of the multiple Ugi reactions, they appear as N-amide substituents on the macrocyclic cores. The use of different diamines and diisocyanides allows an easy variation of the N- to C-directionality and therefore of the position of the exocyclic elements.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXltlSnsb0%253D&md5=727ee77f51cce0fef2b26133d3090c51
        289. 289
          Vercillo, O. E.; Andrade, C. K.; Wessjohann, L. A. Design and synthesis of cyclic RGD pentapeptoids by consecutive Ugi reactions Org. Lett. 2008, 10, 205â 208
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          289
          Design and synthesis of cyclic RGD pentapeptoids by consecutive Ugi reactions
          Vercillo, Otilie E.; Andrade, Carlos Kleber Z.; Wessjohann, Ludger A.
          Organic Letters (2008), 10 (2), 205-208CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7060. (American Chemical Society)
          A new strategy for the synthesis of cyclic peptoids was developed. The approach is based on the use of consecutive Ugi reactions for the assembly of the acyclic peptoid and for the ring closure. Cyclopentapeptoid analogs of the RGD peptides were designed and synthesized using this methodol. The results confirm the versatility and efficiency of the method for the prepn. of cyclic oligopeptoids.

          Rivera, D. G.; Wessjohann, L. A. Supramolecular compounds from multiple Ugi multicomponent macrocyclizations: peptoid-based cryptands, cages, and cryptophanes J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2006, 128, 7122â 7123
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          295
          Supramolecular Compounds from Multiple Ugi Multicomponent Macrocyclizations: Peptoid-based Cryptands, Cages, and Cryptophanes
          Rivera, Daniel G.; Wessjohann, Ludger A.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (22), 7122-7123CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          The first 3-fold multicomponent macrocyclizations of trifunctional building blocks were developed to produce, in one pot, cryptands, cages, and cryptophanes with peptoid tethers carrying addnl. recognition motifs. The straightforward, efficient, and diversity-oriented fashion by which these complex macromulticycles are obtained is suitable for building combinatorial libraries of synthetic receptors with potential applicability in catalysis and supramol. and coordination chem. The strategy also easily allows creation of asym. macromulticyclic cavities, with up to 20 new bonds formed in one pot.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XksFGgsL4%253D&md5=4a608d42f04ab0aae79fb5cdd7a725f6
        296. 296
          Rivera, D. G.; Wessjohann, L. A. Architectural chemistry: synthesis of topologically diverse macromulticycles by sequential multiple multicomponent macrocyclizations J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 3721â 3732
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
          296
          Architectural Chemistry: Synthesis of Topologically Diverse Macromulticycles by Sequential Multiple Multicomponent Macrocyclizations
          Rivera, Daniel G.; Wessjohann, Ludger A.
          Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (10), 3721-3732CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
          A sequential approach involving two multiple multicomponent macrocyclizations including bifunctional building blocks (MiBs) with up to five Ugi-four-component reactions (Ugi-4CR) has been developed to produce nonsym. macromulticycles. Topol. diverse structures, such as nonsym. cryptands and clam- and igloo-shaped macromulticycles were obtained in reaction sequences that comprise the incorporation of up to 13 building blocks by forming 20 new bonds without purifn. of intermediates. Cryptands were produced by a sequential-MiB procedure in which the Ugi-type functional groups of the second MiB are attached to the peptoid backbones from the first multicomponent macrocyclization. These macrobicycles show two completely new features; i.e., three different tether chains can be obtained in one pot, and tertiary amide bonds are used as bridgeheads. Alternatively, the same reaction sequence, i.e., MiB/deprotection/MiB, can be used to produce clam-shaped macrobicycles, demonstrated with a tetrafunctional cholanic steroid as a hinge moiety. Macrotetracycles endowed with igloo-type topologies are accessible by an advanced protocol featuring consecutive double and 3-fold Ugi-4CR-based macrocyclizations. Other building blocks than cholanic steroids employed include aryl, heterocyclic, polyether, and other recognition motifs. The examples given are a first-generation demonstration of an "architectural chem." that allows to construct three-dimensional multimotif covalent mol. "buildings" of unprecedented complexity by design.
          >> More from SciFinder Â®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXit1elsLo%253D&md5=e64d2c28355bb30e9bb9040898360944

          Pirali, T.; Tron, G. C.; Masson, G.; Zhu, J. Ammonium chloride promoted three-component synthesis of 5-iminooxazoline and its subsequent transformation to macrocyclodepsipeptide Org. Lett. 2007, 9, 5275â 5278
          [ACS Full Text ],Â Google Scholar
